Himachal Pradesh High Court

Lucky Kumar vs State Of Himachal Pradesh on 24 July, 2024

 Neutral Citation No. ( 2024:HHC:5722 )

 IN THE HIGH COURT OF HIMACHAL PRADESH, SHIMLA

 Cr. MP (M) No. 1428 of 2024

 .

 Reserved on: 12.07.2024

 Date of Decision: 24.07.2024.

 Lucky Kumar ...Petitioner

 Versus

 State of Himachal Pradesh

 Coram
 r to ...Respondent

 Hon'ble Mr Justice Rakesh Kainthla, Judge.
 Whether approved for reporting?1 No

 For the Petitioner : Mr. Vijender Katoch, Advocate.
 For the Respondent : Mr. Ayushi Negi, Deputy Advocate
 General.

 Rakesh Kainthla, Judge

 The petitioner has filed the present petition for

 seeking regular bail. It has been asserted that the petitioner was

 arrested vide FIR No. 64 of 2024, dated 22.05.2024, registered at

 Police Station Shahpur, District Kangra, H.P. for the commission

 of offences punishable under 
Sections 376
, 
452
, 
323
 and 
506
 of

 the Indian Penal Code (
IPC
). As per the prosecution, the victim

 came out of her home on hearing the noise on 18.05.2024, in the

1

 Whether reporters of Local Papers may be allowed to see the judgment? Yes.

 ::: Downloaded on - 24/07/2024 20:31:58 :::CIS

 2

 night at 12:00 O'clock. A boy ran towards her home. The

 petitioner also came to her home and assaulted her. The

 .

 petitioner thought that the boy had come to meet the victim.

 The petitioner assaulted and raped the victim. He also

 threatened the victim. She remained silent. However, the

 petitioner started defaming her in the locality and started saying

 that he would again rape her. Hence, the victim made a report to

 the police. The police registered the FIR and arrested the

 petitioner. The petitioner is innocent and he was falsely

 implicated. The prosecution story is highly improbable. The

 petitioner had only asked the victim about the person with

 whom she was talking in the middle of the night. The person ran

 away and the victim falsely implicated the present petitioner.

 The victim made a false complaint after four days to save

 herself. The victim is married and was unable to explain why she

 was found with a stranger at midnight. The investigation is

 complete and no recovery is to be effected from the petitioner.

 The petitioner is a permanent resident of District Kangra, HP

 and there is no likelihood of his absconding. The petitioner

 would abide by all the terms and conditions, which may be

 imposed by the Court. Hence, the petition.

 ::: Downloaded on - 24/07/2024 20:31:58 :::CIS

 3

 2. The petition is opposed by filing a status report

 asserting that the victim made a complaint to the police stating

 .

 that a quarrel had taken place in front of her house on

 18.05.2024 at 12:00 am. The victim came out of the house. One

 boy ran towards her home. The petitioner Lucky Kumar also

 came to her home. He gave beatings to her because he thought

 that the boy had visited her house to meet her. The petitioner

 raped the victim and threatened to kill her in case the incident

 was revealed to any person. However, the petitioner was

 defaming her and threatening to rape her. The police registered

 the FIR and arrested the petitioner. The victim and the

 petitioner were medically examined and samples were

 preserved. As per the investigation, the victim and petitioner

 belong to the same village. The petitioner got recovered the stick

 with which he had beaten the victim. The result of the analysis is

 awaited. The petitioner has been in custody since 22.05.2024.

 3. I have heard Mr. Vijender Katoch, learned counsel for

 the petitioner and Ms. Ayushi Negi, learned Deputy Advocate

 General, for the respondent-State.

 ::: Downloaded on - 24/07/2024 20:31:58 :::CIS

 4

 4. Mr Vijender Katoch, learned counsel for the

 petitioner submitted that the prosecution version is highly

 .

 improbable. The incident had occurred in the middle of the night

 when a quarrel has taken place. It is unlikely that the petitioner

 could have raped the victim when the noise could have attracted

 the villagers. The victim would have shouted for help and

 gathered the people. The whole story is false and was made to

 divert attention from the fact that the victim was seen with the

 stranger at her home in the middle of the night. Therefore, he

 prayed that the present petition be allowed and the petitioner be

 released on bail.

 5. Ms. Ayushi Negi, learned Deputy Advocate General

 for the respondent-State submitted that the petitioner had

 raped the victim by entering into her house in the middle of the

 night. Such conduct cannot be lightly condoned. The petitioner

 trespassed in the house of the victim and raped her. She

 submitted that the offence is heinous and the petitioner should

 not be released on bail.

 6. I have given considerable thought to the submissions

 at the bar and have gone through the records carefully.

 ::: Downloaded on - 24/07/2024 20:31:58 :::CIS

 5

 
7. The parameters for granting bail were considered by

 the Hon'ble Supreme Court in 
Bhagwan Singh v. Dilip Kumar
 @

 .

 Deepu @ Depak, 2023 SCC OnLine SC 1059, wherein it was

 observed as under:-

 "12. The grant of bail is a discretionary relief which nec-
 essarily means that such discretion would have to be ex-
 ercised in a judicious manner and not as a matter of

 course. The grant of bail is dependent upon contextual
 facts of the matter being dealt with by the Court and may
 vary from case to case. There cannot be any exhaustive
 parameters set out for considering the application for a

 grant of bail. However, it can be noted that;

 (a) While granting bail the court has to keep in
 mind factors such as the nature of accusations,
 severity of the punishment, if the accusations entail
 a conviction and the nature of evidence in support

 of the accusations;

 (b) reasonable apprehensions of the witnesses be-

 ing tampered with or the apprehension of there be-
 ing a threat for the complainant should also weigh

 with the Court in the matter of grant of bail.

 (c) While it is not accepted to have the entire evi-
 dence establishing the guilt of the accused beyond

 reasonable doubt but there ought to be always a
 prima facie satisfaction of the Court in support of
 the charge.

 (d) Frivolity of prosecution should always be con-
 sidered and it is only the element of genuineness
 that shall have to be considered in the matter of
 grant of bail and in the event of there being some
 doubt as to the genuineness of the prosecution, in
 the normal course of events, the accused is entitled
 to have an order of bail.

 ::: Downloaded on - 24/07/2024 20:31:58 :::CIS

 6

 
13. We may also profitably refer to a decision of this Court
 in 
Kalyan Chandra Sarkar v. Rajesh Ranjan @ Pappu Ya-

 dav (2004) 7 SCC 528 where the parameters to be taken

 .

 into consideration for the grant of bail by the Courts have

 been explained in the following words:

 "11. The law in regard to grant or refusal of bail is
 very well settled. The court granting bail should ex-

 ercise its discretion in a judicious manner and not
 as a matter of course. Though at the stage of grant-
 ing bail a detailed examination of evidence and
 elaborate documentation of the merit of the case

 need not be undertaken, there is a need to indicate
 in such orders reasons for prima facie concluding
 why bail was being granted particularly where the
 accused is charged of having committed a serious

 offence. Any order devoid of such reasons would

 suffer from non-application of mind. It is also nec-
 essary for the court granting bail to consider among
 other circumstances, the following factors also be-
 fore granting bail; they are:

 (a) The nature of accusation and the severity of
 punishment in case of conviction and the nature of

 supporting evidence.

 (b) Reasonable apprehension of tampering with the

 witness or apprehension of threat to the com-

 plainant.

 
(c) Prima facie satisfaction of the court in support
 of the charge. (See Ram Govind Upadhyay v. Sudar-
 shan Singh [(2002) 3 SCC 598: 2002 
SCC (Cri) 688]
 and Puran v. Rambilas
 [(2001) 6 SCC 338: 2001 SCC
 (Cri) 1124].)"

 
8. A similar view was taken in 
State of Haryana vs

 Dharamraj
 2023 SCC Online 1085, wherein it was observed:

 
7. A foray, albeit brief, into relevant precedents is
 warranted. This Court considered the factors to guide the

 ::: Downloaded on - 24/07/2024 20:31:58 :::CIS

 7

 grant of bail in 
Ram Govind Upadhyay v. Sudarshan
 Singh
, (
2002) 3 SCC 598 and Kalyan Chandra
 Sarkar v. Rajesh Ranjan
, (2004) 7 SCC 528. In Prasanta

 .

 
Kumar Sarkar v. Ashis Chatterjee
, (2010) 14 SCC 496, the

 relevant principles were restated thus:

 
'9. ... It is trite that this Court does not, normally, interfere
 with an order passed by the High Court granting or

 rejecting bail to the accused. However, it is equally
 incumbent upon the High Court to exercise its discretion
 judiciously, cautiously and strictly in compliance with the
 basic principles 
laid down in
 a plethora of decisions of

 this Court on the point. It is well settled that, among other
 circumstances, the factors to be borne in mind while
 considering an application for bail are:

 r (i) whether there is any prima facie or reasonable

 ground to believe that the accused had committed
 the offence;

 (ii) nature and gravity of the accusation;

 (iii) severity of the punishment in the event of
 conviction;

 (iv) danger of the accused absconding or fleeing if

 released on bail;

 (v) character, behaviour, means, position and
 standing of the accused;

 (vi) likelihood of the offence being repeated;

 (vii) reasonable apprehension of the witnesses
 being influenced; and

 (viii) danger, of course, of justice being
 thwarted by grant of bail.'

 9. The contents of the FIR show that a quarrel was

 taking place outside the home of the victim at 12:00 am on

 18.05.2024 when one person ran towards the house of the victim.

 ::: Downloaded on - 24/07/2024 20:31:58 :::CIS

 8

 The petitioner followed him. The petitioner gave beatings to the

 victim and also raped her. The victim reported the matter to the

 .

 police on 22.05.2024 after four days of the incident. She

 explained the delay by saying that the petitioner was defaming

 her and threatening her to rape her. These averments show that

 the complete truth is not being disclosed. There is a force in the

 submission of learned counsel for the petitioner that prima facie

 the petitioner could not have raped the victim when a quarrel

 had taken place and any cry would have attracted the people.

 Further, the petitioner was following the person and would be

 more concerned about preventing the person's escape. Prima

 facie it appears that the prosecution is not telling the complete

 truth and it is difficult to believe the prosecution's version.

 10. The petitioner has been in custody since 22.05.2024.

 The status report does not show that the presence of the

 petitioner is required for any purpose. The petitioner has been

 sent to judicial custody, which means that his custodial

 interrogation is not required. The status report further shows

 that the result of the analysis is still awaited. Some time will be

 consumed in preparing the challan after the receipt of the

 ::: Downloaded on - 24/07/2024 20:31:58 :::CIS

 9

 report. The petitioner cannot be kept inside the jail indefinitely

 awaiting his trial.

 .

 11. The petitioner stated that he is a permanent resident

 of District Kangra, HP, which is not denied in the status report.

 Thus, there is no chance of the petitioner's absconding and not

 facing the trial.

 12.

 It was submitted that the petitioner and the victim

 belong to the same village and the petitioner can intimidate the

 victim. The bail cannot be denied on this ground alone. Suffice it

 to say that the police would have the right to approach the Court,

 in case the petitioner violates the conditions of bail.

 13. In view of the aforesaid discussion, the present

 petition is allowed and the petitioner is ordered to be released on

 bail in the sum of ₹1,00,000/- with one surety of the like

 amount to the satisfaction of the learned Trial Court. While on

 bail, the petitioner will abide by the following terms and

 conditions: -

 (i) The petitioner will not intimidate the witnesses nor will
 he influence any evidence in any manner whatsoever.

 (ii) The petitioner shall attend the trial in case a charge sheet
 is presented against him and will not seek unnecessary
 adjournments.

 ::: Downloaded on - 24/07/2024 20:31:58 :::CIS

 10

 (iii) The petitioner will not leave the present address for a
 continuous period of seven days without furnishing the
 address of intending visit to the SHO, the Police Station

 .

 concerned and the Trial Court.

 (iv) The petitioner will furnish his mobile number, and social
 media contact to the Police and the Court and will abide
 by the summons/notices received from the Police/Court

 through SMS/WhatsApp/Social Media Account. In case of
 any change in the mobile number or social media
 accounts, the same will be intimated to the Police/Court
 within five days from the date of the change.

 14.

 It is expressly made clear that in case of violation of

 any of these conditions, the prosecution will have a right to file a

 petition for cancellation of the bail.

 15. The observation made herein before shall remain

 confined to the disposal of the petition and will have no bearing,

 whatsoever, on the merits of the case.

 (Rakesh Kainthla)
 Judge
 24th July, 2024

 (Shamsh Tabrez)

suffer from non-application of mind. It is also nec-

r (i) whether there is any prima facie or reasonable

ground to believe that the accused had committed

taking place outside the home of the victim at 12:00 am on

The petitioner followed him. The petitioner gave beatings to the
victim and also raped her. The victim reported the matter to the
